column3: as they brought various industry experiences to the job. 	The first 3 weeks are brutal because you have to stay late for planning On Cue

column1: 3	Karine	Hsu	karinehsu@college.harvard.edu	Cue Ball Capital	Summer Associate	1	7	summer	2014	\N	2014-08-25 17:59:04	2014-08-25 17:59:04	Standard. Ya know
2. Went to Chicago for consulting project for portfolio company
4. Sat in on 	The internship program was run by one of the full-time associates
column2: Andrew Fu. He was a great person to talk to and ask for help with work and life advice. One of the other full-time associates
column4: wasn't directly in charge of the internship program but was also a great resource because he had just graduated from Harvard College and was very relatable.	-I would recommend my internship to someone who wants experience in VC
column5: but not someone who wants a structured internship program. The company only has around 6 full-time people
column6: so it's very much a startup in itself and so there were often times when a lot of the interns were unsure of what to do during the day.

column1: - The expectations for On Cue really threw me off in the beginning. We had hours from 9AM- 11PM for two weeks doing very meaningless tasks
column2: like creating name tags. I wish someone had told me the prep for On Cue
I would recommend the internship because of the people. The full-time people were really fun to be around. The other interns were phenomenal
column4: although it did seem like they hired more interns than they really needed. There were some fun company bonding events
column5: like going to Spectacle Island for the day to relax
column6: and Cue Ball really spends extravagant amounts of money on food and wine for lunches and dinners very often. :)

5	James	Ho	jamesho@college.harvard.edu	Harvard Management Company	Public Markets Credit Intern	1	2	summer	2014	\N	2014-08-25 23:33:47	2014-08-25 23:33:47	medium	A mix of spreadsheets to help them analyze some trading ideas
column2: and buildups of the financial statements for companies that they're looking at.	Mentorship is pretty great. You get to meet with the full timers 2-3 times a week for teaching sessions and to ask any of the questions you want. They're also very open to you asking for career advice.	Desk culture is very chill
column3: you have to get in pretty early in the morning but you do around 11 hours a day. As long as you get all your work done you can leave when you want to. You get to learn a ton as long as you're proactive about learning and you show them that you're eager and reliable. Culture and style is more similar to that of a trading desk
column4: where everything is pretty fast paced and trade focused. Really smart people on the desk that have 20+ years of industry experience
column5: so they're essentially experts in the credit markets.

column1: 6	Anson	Kahng	ansonkahng@college.harvard.edu	Google	Tech Intern	1	1700	summer	2014	\N	2014-08-26 02:19:30	2014-08-26 02:19:30	Standard. Ya know
column2: the usual 9-5.	I worked on a data mining project with fleet-wide machine data. Basically an applied machine learning project.	My host was always there when I needed help
column3: but it was mostly a hands-off mentorship deal.	Amenities are great (gyms
column9: but you don't get to meet that many other interns over the course of the summer
column10: and sometimes the size of the company serves to make you feel more isolated rather than more included. The experience also really depends on the host (a friend of mine had a rather incompetent host and did not have a good time at all
column11: whereas my host was very competent and helped me immensely)
column12: so take host-matching seriously and ask lots of questions in that interview. Also
column13: make sure to take weekends and explore the bay area -- find a good balance between work and fun.

column1: 7	Sami	Ghoche	samighoche@college.harvard.edu	Palantir Technologies	Infrastructure Engineer	1	200	summer	2014	7000	2014-08-26 09:03:06	2014-08-26 09:03:06	medium	I worked on the Palantir online map product.
I extended a web automation framework then used it to write end to end automated tests and harnesses for the product
column2: and I developped some important features for the map.	Pretty good! I personally didn't have the best mentor (he was a bit awkward) but I absolutely loved my team and you learn just as much from them as you do your mentor. Three weeks in
column3: you're expected to give a one hour talk about the company products
column4: focusing on your area of work.	I absolutely loved it
column5: I would definitely go back (for full time if not for another internship). It's a great company and you're surrounded by very smart and very hardworking people
column6: and the infrastructure team (especially its lead) is awesome. There were a lot of team bonding events
column8: and very often just drinks at the office and nearby bars. You tend to work more than your typical tech internship I think
column9: but the pay is definitely nice. Great internship!
